newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Indonesia eases sugar marketing restrictions.
newsitem.headline: Indonesia eases sugar marketing restrictions.

text.p: Indonesia will ease marketing restrictions on new sugar mills in an effort to encourage new investment in the industry, the Jakarta Post newspaper reported on Wednesday.

Agriculture Minister Syarifuding Baharsyah said the government would allow new mills in the eastern provinces to market 75 percent of their output themselves and those in the western provinces 50 percent of their production.
"The government has decided to ease the marketing restrictions to stimulate private investors to develop new sugar mills and sugarcane plantations outside Java," he was quoted as saying.
The present sugar marketing system requires mills to sell their output to the National Logistics Agency (BULOG) at the government-mandated price.
Domestic consumers have been subsiding the inefficient industry in recent years as government prices have been higher than international prices.
"The government would also help investors acquire land for sugarcane plantations to speed up the development of their projects," Baharsyah said.
The report said Indonesia plans to close down 27 of its 57 state-owned sugar mills in Java which have been rendered inefficient because of very old machinery.
National sugar output has been declining over the last three years to 2.4 million tonnes in 1995 when Indonesian sugar imports, mostly from Thailand, amounted to more than 300,000 tonnes.
